ait.finite_state_machine module

This module defines a finite state machine

class ait.finite_state_machine.FiniteStateMachine(self_circuit=False)[source]

Bases: object

Class of finite state machine (FSM)

A finite state machine is consists of a finite number of states and the transitions among the states. Our implementation of the FSM is based on a directed graph, in which each vertex represents a state and each directed edge represents an event that triggers state transition.

add_state(state: State)[source]

Add a state in the graph as a vertex, if a vertex with the same state name already exist, do nothing.

Parameters:

state (State) – the new state

add_transition(source: State, target: State, event: Event, unique: bool = True)[source]

Add a transition from source state to target state when event happens. The source and target state are stored in the graph as vertices and the event is a directed edge from the source to the target.

Parameters:

  • transition (Transition) – the tuple of a source state, a target state and the event triggers the transition.

  • unique (bool, optional) – keep the transition unique, defaults to True. if there is a transition with the same source/target/event, do nothing.

build_graph() → None[source]

construct graph from the matrix

Raises:

ValueError – a ValueError exception will be raised if there are invalid transitions in the matrix

export_graph(filename: str, layout: str) → None[source]

Generate a plotting of the graph data and save in a file using given layout :param filename: the file to store the plotting, support svg, png, pdf :param layout: the layout algorithm

get_shortest_paths(v_from: str, v_to: list = None) → list[Edge][source]

Calculates the shortest path from a source vertex to a target vertex in a graph.

Parameters:

  • v_from – the source vertex of the path

  • v_to – the target vertex of the path, default None indicating to calculate paths to all the vertices

Returns:

list of sequences of edges of the shortest path to all the targets, sorted by length

get_state(name: str) → State[source]

Get a state by name

Parameters:

name (str) – the name of the state

Returns:

the state object if exists, otherwise None

Return type:

State

get_transitions(source_name: str = '', target_name: str = '', event_name: str = '') → list[Edge][source]
path_to_str(eids: list[int]) → str[source]
read_csv(filename: str) → None[source]

import the state machine matrix from a csv file the first line of the csv is “ori_state”, “state_detail”, event1, event2, … starting from the 2nd row

  • the 1st column represents the indexes of the states starts from 0

  • the 2nd column is the explanation of the state

  • the rest cells are the target state index when an event received at the original state

look tests/example.csv for example

Parameters:

filename – the csv filename
